did.abstract: The University of Michigan Hospital system has evolved and expanded since its inception in 1869. The various hospitals, such as the C.S. Mott Children's Hospital and W.K. Kellogg Eye Center, provide medical treatment to the Ann Arbor, Michigan area. The Hospitals records contain five series: Hospital Administration, Nursing, Committees/Councils, Patient Files, and Hospital Buildings. This collection includes meeting minutes, patient files, director files, correspondence, and more.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The Hospital records (donor no. 2289) were acquired in several accessions beginning in 1966. A portion of the record group came from the University of Michigan Medical School (donor no. 647). In April 2000, 26.5 linear feet were added to the collection. In April 2015 Associate Director of Nursing records were added as a series (donor no. 2289)

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open to research except for these exceptions: Boxes 40-48 are closed except to the donors of the records; patient case records found in (but not limited to) boxes 2-9 are open after the researcher has read and signed the "Patient Record Access Agreement. Registration Books are closed.

The Hospital record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Patient/Client Records -- Boxes 2-9 and oversize volumes 2-33
Architectural Drawings -- Boxes 40-48
Executive Officers Records -- Boxes 130-132, 138-152.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Hospitals (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

chronitem.event: A professor’s home on North University is converted into a small hospital (20-24 beds) for patients, becoming the first hospital controlled by a university medical school.
Two pavilions are added to the existing hospital, for a total of 60 beds. The construction is made possible by state appropriation as well as funding from the city of Ann Arbor.
Appropriations from the Michigan Legislature, combined with funding from the city of Ann Arbor allow for the construction of a new hospital, built on Catherine Street over the next two years.

The new Catherine Street Hospital opens and is shared by the medical department and the homeopathic medical college. The homeopathic medical college moves to another location in 1900, with the vacated space taken over by University Hospital.
The 75-bed Palmer Ward, one of the first children’s wards in the United States, opens in the Catherine Street Hospital.

Jay B. Draper becomes hospital superintendent, serving until 1915. During his tenure, the hospital becomes responsible for its own finances, resulting in a surplus. The resulting complaints lead to the formation of a new Hospital Committee, created by Regental approval (January 1912), to oversee the hospital.
The University opens Michigan’s first psychiatric hospital.
Harley A. Haynes (M.D. 1902) is appointed director of the University Hospital and is one of the earliest to bring cost accounting to hospital administration.
The Catherine Street Hospital is replaced by University Hospital (also known as Old Main Hospital), a 700-bed facility, built at a cost of $4.4 million.
University Hospital offers the first physician training program in thoracic surgery.
The University of Michigan Base Hospital (General Hospital No. 298) is organized and subsequently serves in England, France, and Belgium.
Women’s Hospital opens as a 66,822 square foot facility. The Birth Center was one of the first facilities to offer single-room maternity care.
The Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Hospital opens.
C.S. Mott Children’s Hospital opens its doors, as the University’s first hospital devoted entirely to children. The 272,732 square foot facility houses 200 beds.
The James and Lynelle Holden Perinatal Hospital is built, providing care for premature and critically ill infants.
The Regents approve the Bylaws for the Executive Board of University Hospital.
The W.K. Kellogg Eye Center, a 32-bed facility, is established, providing patient care, education and research in eye diseases.
The Regents approve the creation of the Finance and Personnel Committee, which serves as a governing authority for financial matters and strategic planning.
The University begins its Survival Flight program, a hospital-based airborne emergency medical service - the first in the state.

The University Hospital and A. Alfred Taubman Health Care Center open. The 11-story hospital is nearly 1.8 million square feet in size and holds 550 beds. The A. Alfred Taubman Health Care Center, which houses 120 outpatient clinics. The conversion from Old Main into the new facilities takes place on Feb. 14.
M-CARE, a University HMO plan is developed. As of the year 2002, it serves over 200,000 members in 14 counties, offering HMO, point of service, Medicare and Medicaid plans.
The hospitals expand, adding integrated services for women and children in new space and renovated units in existing hospitals.
Creation of Michigan Health Care Corporation, and University of Michigan Health System
The University of Michigan moves its cancer and geriatrics clinical and research programs into the $88 million Cancer Center and Geriatrics Center Building.
The Health System creates the Department of Emergency Medicine.
The University of Michigan Health System establishes the nation's first Depression Center.
Construction begins on the C.S. Mott Children's Hospital and Women's Hospital addition after receiving a $25 million grant from the Mott Foundation
The University of Michigan Cardiovascular clinical building opens to provide support for heart, vascular, and stroke care patients.
The Health System receives a $15 million gift from the Ted and Jane Von Voigtlander Foundation to begin construction on a new women's hospital.
The new Brehm Tower at the W.K. Kellogg Eye Center opens, increasing the capacity of providing eye care to patients.
The new C.S. Mott Women's Hospital and Von Voigtlander Women's Hospital opens. The Adult Emergency Department and Psychiatric Emergency area is expanded.
A master affiliation agreement is signed with the Michigan hospitals of Trinity Health

Ground is broken on a new outpatient center, the Northville Health Center. University of Michigan managed inpatient beds are opened in the Chelsea Community Hospital and Saint Joseph Mercy-Ann Arbor Hospital. The Cardiovascular Center is named in honor of Samuel and Jean Frankel.

bioghist.p: During the early years of the University Hospital operation (1869-1874), the institution was entrusted to the care of janitors and matrons. In 1874, a house physician was placed in charge, beginning a series of different titles, ranging from steward, to superintendent and later, director. The list of early overseers is sketchy.
The University Hospital Board in Control was replaced by the University Hospital Executive Board in 1974.
In 1978, the Board of Clinical Directors was superseded by the Nursing Executive Committee
In 1982 the Planning Advisory Committee became the Public Advisory Board.
The Replacement Hospital Project was dissolved in June 1984 with the formation of the Vice Provost Advisory Board, under the administration of the Vice Provost for Medical Affairs.
In January 1989 the Hospital Executive Team became the Hospital Advisory Group.
In 1997 the U-M Board of regents approves "University of Michigan Health System" encompassing the Hospitals and Health Centers, Medical School, M-Care, and Michigan Health Corp.

The School of Nursing becomes a part of the University of Michigan Health System in 2008. All of the hospitals and many of the clinical units are transitioned into a computerized order entry system called UM-CareLink.

scopecontent.p: the University of Michigan Hospitals records include administrative correspondence and topical files; committee files; ward reports and other case records; annual reports of hospital departments; records of hospital activities, and clippings

controlaccess.head: Subjects:

controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Replacement Hospital Project.

scopecontent.p: The Hospital Administration series (66 linear feet) contains the records of various directors of the University of Michigan Hospitals, as well as the executive boards and councils. This series is broken up into 8 subseries, each one focusing on a different administrator or committee. Included amongst the administrators are some of the directors, executive directors, associate directors, and assistant directors.

The Dalston, Jeptha W. subseries (1 linear foot) contains documentation from Dalston's time as the executive director of the hospital system, from 1975 to 1985. This subseries contains a volume of Dalston's correspondence. More records relating to Dalston can be found within the subseries of his successor, John Forsyth.

The Executive Director's Council subseries (4 linear feet) contain records from the Executive Director's Advisory Council, as well as the similar Executive Director's Council. Included within this subseries are mainly the meeting minutes of these administrative councils as well as other project files. This subseries contains records from 1980 to 1995 and is arranged chronologically.

The Forsyth, John subseries (29 linear feet) makes up a bulk of the Hospital Administration series. These materials contain records from Forsyth's time as the Executive Director of the Hospitals, between the years 1985 and 1996. This subseries documents the full range of activities in which hospital executives participated in the 1980s and 1990s, including affiliations, negations, and merger talks with other local hospitals as well as with the University of Michigan Medical School, relations with the state of Michigan, the development of a health maintenance organization (HMO), and financial and strategic planning for a major medical institution. Records relating to hospital departments contain some annual reports as well as full-scale reviews of the departmental programs. Some of the materials in this subseries also contain documentation of some of projects and actions performed by Forsyth's predecessor, Dalston.

The Haynes, Harley subseries (4 linear feet) consists of records relating to the actions of the Hospital Director (precursor to the role of executive director) from 1924 to 1945. This subseries is completely comprised of director's correspondence, which is arranged alphabetically by topic.

The Howe, Arlene subseries (3 linear feet) contains material from 1973 to 1978, in which she spent time as the Assistant Director of the Hospitals. Topical files are contained within the subseries, and are arranged alphabetically. They include information on the various projects that Howe took part in, many of them concerning the construction of some of the hospital buildings. There are also committee meeting minutes that Howe was involved with, documenting building renovations and space allocation.

The University Hospitals Executive Board (17 linear feet) subseries consist of materials from the Executive Board, along with related administrative committees including the Executives Council, Executive Staff, Board in Control, and Executive Board. The materials range from 1919 to 1996 and mostly made up of the minutes from these board meetings and executive directories.

The Warren, Larry subseries (3 linear feet) covers the years 1996 to 2006 during his time as the Executive Director of the Hospitals. The subseries is primarily made up of videotapes from the Executive Director's Forum as well as volumes of Warren's correspondence.

The Zugich, John subseries (5 linear feet) consists of the topical files of the Associate Director of the Hospitals during the mid-1970s. Materials include records of hospital projects, including surveys and studies, which Zugich took part in. This subseries is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: The Nursing series (32 linear feet) contains information on the various nursing programs provided by the Hospitals, as well as nursing administrators. Many of these records document the various programs made available to assist and educate nurses, and the administrators that have helped implement them. The series contains various nursing meeting minutes, director correspondence, and nursing program manuals.

The Associate Director for Nursing subseries (5 linear feet) is made up of records from the nursing administrators; Ann Vose, Marjorie Jackson, Sally Sample, and Sue McMahon. Administrative council meeting minutes and topical files make up a bulk of the subseries. Much of this subseries also consists of minutes and projects relating to the various nursing committees. The series is arranged by the creator of the records which includes Sue McMahon, Sally Sample, and Ann Vose (along with Marjorie Jackson and Sally Sample).

The Clinical Nursing Specialist Program subseries (1 linear foot) consist of a small number of records relating to the development of this program. The subseries also contain papers presented at clinical nursing symposiums as well as information about mental health nurses and nursing shortages.

The Educational Services for Nursing subseries (6 linear feet) contains records documenting the educational programs and projects for nurses. Included within the subseries are the pamphlets, videotapes, and the educational conferences used to help educate nurses and nursing students within the University of Michigan. A large number of binders are contained within this subseries and include orientation manuals, program manuals, and project overviews. This subseries also contains a number of newsletters sent out by educational services department, and policies for units within the Educational Services for Nursing group. This subseries is arranged alphabetically and covers the years 1978 to 1995.

The Nursing Administration subseries (5 linear feet) contains records from the committees, and decisions made by the administration as a whole. This includes minutes from committee meetings from the administrative meetings, as well as the Continuing Care Committee. Goals and objectives are contained within the subseries and help document some of the projects and decisions that have been implemented by the administration.

The Nursing Services subseries (1 linear foot) consists of meeting minutes, reports from staff members, various policy manuals, as well as some photographs. This subseries is arranged alphabetically and contains materials from 1969 to 1986. The subseries contains materials relating to nursing needs, nursing committees, search for project directors, and many other tasks relating to the services offered to University of Michigan nurses.

scopecontent.p: The Committees/Councils series (37 linear feet) contains materials on a number of committees of on the different functions within the many hospitals. The series is split into 10 subseries, each one offering documentation on the decisions and actions of specific committees. Each of the subseries solely contains minutes of the committee meetings, except in the case of the Medical Staff subseries which also consists of data and statistics compiled by this group. Records relating to the committees of the executive directors and executive board can be found in the Hospital Administration series.

did.unittitle: Record Book 1979 of the Committee to Review Clinical Chairman Search Procedures
Clinical Delivery Systems Executive Committee (CDSEC) Minutes
Clinical Delivery Systems Management Team (CDSMT)/Systems Management Team (SMT) Minutes
Executive Committee on Clinical Affairs (ECCA) Minutes

scopecontent.p: The Patient Files series (14 linear feet) contains records pertaining to the patients of the hospital system. This series is split into 4 sub series: Case Records, Hospital Reports, Hospital School for Patients, and Record Books/Registration Books. Some of the records contained within this series are restricted as described in the access restrictions page of the finding aid. The records within these subseries include case files, hospital registration books, and other patient files.

scopecontent.p: The Hospital Buildings series (18 linear feet) contains the designs and documentation of the various hospital buildings. The series is split into the Architectural Drawings and Replacement Hospital Project subseries. The bulk of this series consists of documents relating to the design and construction of new hospital buildings as well as the renovation of existing hospital structures, including meeting minutes and executive reports.
